9. This technique has been applied to LMCX-2, resulting in the detection of a periodic signal in the spectroscopic dataset that is identified as the orbital period.
10. The bowen region in the spectra of LMCX-2 shows the presence of narrow emission lines that are identified as coming from the irradiated side of the companion, giving the first ever constraints on the system parameters of LMCX-2.

The axial anomaly, a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, has been analyzed using the renormalization procedure and the path integral formalism. An alternative approach, proposed by Dolgov and Zakharov, interprets the anomaly as an infrared phenomenon using dispersion relations and the triangular diagram. This interpretation sheds light on the physical meaning of anomalous chiral symmetry breaking and the cancellation of mass singularities in polarized radiative decays.

1. Salient object detection, the task of simulating human attention to prioritize objects for high-level processing, has recently gained popularity in computer vision.
2. It has various applications including recognition, image and video compression, video summarization, media re-targeting and photo collage, image quality assessment, image segmentation, content-based image retrieval and image collection browsing, image editing and manipulating, visual tracking, object discovery, and human-robot interaction.
3. A large number of saliency detection methods have been proposed, but they often struggle with complex scenes containing multiple objects.
4. The process of salient object detection involves selecting objects to process and segmenting the object area.
5. Current models perform well on datasets with single objects and low clutter but their performance on complex scenes with multiple objects is unclear.
6. The lack of suitable benchmark datasets and a widely agreed objective definition of the most salient object are hindering the development of models for complex scenes.
7. The paper aims to provide solutions for these problems and discover the weakest link in the possible failure of models when migrating to complex scenes.
8. Related topics to visual saliency modeling and salient object detection include object importance, object proposal generation, memorability, scene clutter, image interestingness, video interestingness, surprise, image quality assessment, scene typicality, aesthetic, and attributes.
9. The paper discusses the differences between models defining saliency as "where people look" and models defining saliency as "which objects stand out", and the relationship between saliency judgments and eye movements.

1. Heegaard Floer theory is a decorated topological quantum field theory (TQFT) in 2 dimensions, constructed by Ozsváth and Szabó, which associates a vector space to a closed, connected, oriented 3-manifold with a τ2-structure, and a map to a 4-dimensional cobordism decorated with a τ2-structure.
2. The maps can be used to detect exotic smooth structures on 4-manifolds with boundary.
3. For example, two homeomorphic but not diffeomorphic 4-manifolds can be obtained by performing a log transform with odd multiplicity on a regular fiber of the nucleus of an elliptic surface.
4. The original definitions of the vector spaces and maps in Heegaard Floer theory involved counting pseudoholomorphic disks and triangles in symmetric products of Riemann surfaces, which are related to the 3-manifolds and cobordisms involved via Heegaard diagrams.
5. Sarkar and the third author showed that every 3-manifold admits a Heegaard diagram that is nice in the sense that the curves split the diagram into elementary domains, all but one of which are bigons or rectangles.
6. Using such a diagram, holomorphic disks in the symmetric product can be counted combinatorially, giving a combinatorial description of the Heegaard Floer homology of any 3-manifold and the hat version of Heegaard Floer homology of null-homologous knots and links in any 3-manifold.
7. The goal of the paper is to give a combinatorial procedure for calculating the ranks of the maps when the cobordism is between two 3-manifolds with the property that the induced maps are surjective.
8. This case includes all cobordisms for which the map on the τ2-torsion subgroup is an isomorphism, as well as all those consisting of only 2-handle additions.

1. The paper extends the results of Yetter, Gerstenhaber, and Gerstenhaber and Schack on the infinitesimal deformation theory of associative algebras and poset-indexed diagrams of associative algebras to a deformation theory for arbitrary pasting diagrams of X-linear categories, X-linear functors, and natural transformations.
2. The paper establishes that obstructions are cocycles for deformation complexes of pasting diagrams in general, and considers deformations of pasting diagrams in which specified functors or natural transformations are required to be deformed trivially.
3. The paper also makes explicit a point overlooked in previous theorems, and describes chain maps induced by pasting compositions on the full deformation complexes when X3 is a composable pasting diagram.

1. The text discusses the importance of understanding the physical picture behind observable phenomena in physics, rather than just calculating numbers.
2. In crystals, for example, the fundamental degrees of freedom are ions in the lattice, electrons, and the electromagnetic field. However, to understand electric conductivity and heat capacity, it is more useful to work with "heavy electrons" with dynamical mass, phonons, and their interaction.
3. The complicated electromagnetic interaction of electrons with ions in the lattice is hidden in the dynamical mass of the electron, and the interactions among ions in the lattice are responsible for collective excitations of the lattice, known as phonons.
4. In QCD, the theory becomes too complicated at the scale of 1 GeV, making it difficult to determine the relevant physics for the nucleon mass and its low-energy properties.
5. The spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry is identified as the most important QCD phenomenon for the nucleon mass and its low-energy properties.
6. Beyond the scale of spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry, light and strange baryons can be viewed as systems of three constituent quarks that interact by the exchange of Goldstone bosons (pseudoscalar mesons), vector and scalar mesons, and are subject to confinement.
7. The chiral symmetry of QCD is spontaneously broken down to a subgroup by the QCD vacuum, leading to the appearance of an octet of pseudoscalar mesons of low mass and the acquisition of a dynamical mass by valence (practically massless) quarks.
8. The nonzero value of the quark condensates for the light flavors represents the order parameter for the spontaneously broken chiral symmetry.
9. The text also discusses the role of the Nambu and Jona-Lasinio model in illustrating the general aspects of spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry in QCD.

This invention describes a calcium phosphate-coated implantable medical device that minimizes immune response and stores and releases one or more medicinally active agents. The unique calcium-phosphate coating process involves the use of a biodegradable polymer coating impregnated with medically active agents, which are released through leaching to the arterial wall and the blood stream. The polymer coatings are flexible and generally non-thrombogenic, but even biodegradable polymers can cause an inflammatory response and may be quickly depleted, leading to exposure of the bare metal surface and potential adverse tissue reactions. The invention aims to discover materials for coating implantable medical devices that are entirely biocompatible and can deliver pharmaceutically active agents to a targeted site. Porous coatings may be used to accept and release drugs in a controlled manner, and calcium phosphate materials, which are fully bio-compatible and bio-resorbable, are proposed as a suitable coating material. Hydroxyapatite ceramics, in particular, are highlighted as a principal inorganic component of bone and a potential candidate for coating-based drug encapsulation and delivery systems.

1. The present invention is related to nerve regeneration, specifically to nerve conduits for the regeneration of peripheral nerves.
2. Current treatments for peripheral nerve injuries include end-to-end suturing and autograft or allograft biological tissue, but both have limitations.
3. Tissue engineering and biomaterials suggest that nerve repair and regeneration may be achieved through natural or synthetic nerve guidance conduits (NGCs).
4. FDA-approved tissue engineered nerve devices have been available for several years, but they lack the proper physical topography or chemical cues for nerve repair and regeneration and are limited to a critical nerve gap of approximately 4 cm.
5. Current laboratorial NGCs developed using haptotactic strategies alone are not yet comparable to autograft, with issues such as insufficient cross-sectional area, inhibition of cell-cell interaction, and inadequate design of intra-luminal guidance channels/filament.
6. An embodiment of the present invention provides a fabricated implantable NGC with an inner spiral structured porous sheet, which can serve as a medical device to treat peripheral nerve injuries and restore function.
7. The spiral structure facilitates regeneration of nerve tissues, and the chambers at the proximal and distal ends allow for nerve stumps to be sutured without tension.
8. The spiral conduit is tunable, with its length and diameter controllable depending on how it is to be used.
9. The method of fabricating the conduit does not limit its length, enabling its application for longer gap repair/regeneration for peripheral nerve injuries.
10. The invention also provides a process for fabricating an implantable NGC, which can be used as a medical device for facilitating the repair and regeneration of nerve tissues.

1. The invention describes new and improved rail connectors for seat base support assemblies, particularly for sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, and flexible steel bands.
2. The rail connectors are designed to provide torsioning, dynamic uplift, expansion-contraction, and leverage-amplification, resulting in improved seat performance.
3. The first form of the rail connector uses a pre-stressed, close-wound coil spring with attachment arms, which can be wound on a transverse or longitudinal axis and have a leverage-amplified torsioning capability.
4. The second form of the rail connector uses a pre-stressed, cantilever spring configuration and can be used with a sinuous spring band having leverage-amplified torsioning incorporated.
5. The connectors provide seat spring enhancement, combining the four essential seat-force-generators and producing the four most desired seat-performance characteristics.
6. The invention is illustrated in various figures, showing different forms and modifications of the rail connectors in use with spring band assemblies.
7. The first form of the rail connector is fabricated of eleven (11) gauge wire, with a coil section and attachment legs that connect to the spring band and rail.
8. The second form of the rail connector uses a cantilever principle to provide dynamic uplift to the band at the back rail and is fabricated of spring steel wire of relatively heavy gauge.
9. The connectors can also be used to connect other forms of seat base support means to the frame rails, providing dynamic uplift adjacent the back rail.
10. The invention can be modified and improved while still falling within the true spirit and scope of the invention.

The present disclosure describes an anvil assembly for use with a surgical stapling device, specifically designed to prevent damage to the anvil assembly during attachment to the stapling device. The anvil assembly includes an anvil shaft with a proximal portion having flexible legs that define a first longitudinal bore, and an anvil head assembly secured to the distal portion of the anvil shaft. A stabilizing collet, positioned within the first longitudinal bore, supports and protects the flexible legs from damage during attachment of the anvil assembly to the stapling device. The collet is cylindrical, substantially rigid, and has a distal end with cantilevered fingers, each having a protrusion that secures the collet within the first longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft. The anvil shaft defines holes adjacent the distal end of each longitudinal channel, which receive the protrusions of the collet. The anvil head assembly is pivotally secured to the anvil shaft and supports an annular anvil plate with staple deforming pockets.

1. The present invention is a container for a blender with a lining made of a rigid material such as metal or glass to shield the inner wall of the receptacle from collision with rigid materials.
2. The lining has teeth on its inner wall to grate fibers of vegetables and fruits, reducing the duration of grinding and the related oxidization activity.
3. The lining can be shaped as a half-mask or a whole-mask, and is combined to the inner wall of the cup by injection molding.
4. The cup has several vertical ribs and a number of vertical stopper members that correspond to the ribs, with hollowed troughs on the reverse side of the wall of the lining to match and receive the ribs.
5. The lining can also have a number of teeth projected up from the top end of the stopper members for further grinding of the fibers.
6. In the second embodiment, the lining is shaped as a half-mask with prop stands and a horizontal ring for easy mounting inside the cup and holding by the user.
7. In the third embodiment, the lining is shaped as a half-mask composed of several lining pieces with a stopper member and teeth on the same side, and a lip for easy assembly and disassembly.
8. In the fourth embodiment, the lining is shaped as a whole mask composed of several lining pieces with a horizontal ring for easy assembly, disassembly, and holding by the user.

A garnish pick is disclosed that includes one or more appendages, which can serve as skewering shafts or hooks for securing the pick to a container. The angles and orientations of the appendages can simulate the appearance of organisms or their parts. The garnish pick can have multiple appendages, some serving as hooks and others as skewering shafts. The pick can be used in various environments, such as martini glasses, and can be made of different materials. The construction details of the garnish picks can vary, and they can have different shapes, sizes, and cross-sectional areas.

1. The present invention is a device and algorithm for a combined cardiomyostimulator and cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator, used in a cardiac assist system for patients needing augmented cardiac output.
2. The system includes a cardiomyoplasty, which is a muscle-powered cardiac assist system, and an implantable pulse generator that senses heart contractions and stimulates the muscle tissue to contract in synchrony with the heart.
3. Patients with chronic cardiac output deficiencies face an increased risk for cardiac arrhythmic episodes, which can be life-threatening.
4. Some cardiac assist systems combine a muscle stimulator and a cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator to provide both muscle-powered cardiac assistance and therapeutic cardiac electrical stimulation.
5. However, muscle stimulation can interfere with the reliable sensing of cardiac events, especially during ventricular arrhythmias when the cardiac signals have low amplitudes.
6. The present invention temporarily stops or inhibits skeletal muscle stimulation once an arrhythmia is sensed, allowing for accurate detection and diagnosis of arrhythmias.
7. The system also features skeletal muscle stimulation while charging for defibrillation, which limits the increase in defibrillation thresholds and allows for smaller capacitors or lower voltages.
8. The device and algorithm of the present invention provide a cardiac assist system that permits the rapid detection of a cardiac arrhythmia and provides cardiac assistance during a cardiac arrhythmia.

1. The invention describes an accommodating intraocular lens (IOL) device for implantation in a lens chamber of a subject's eye to treat cataracts and presbyopia.
2. Cataract surgery is a common procedure, but conventional IOL devices primarily focus on distance vision and do not correct for presbyopia, requiring the use of reading glasses.
3. There is a need for an effective surgical intervention to correct for presbyopia, which cannot be treated by conventional LASIK procedures.
4. The IOL device generally comprises two lens portions: a first lens portion provides accommodative power, and a second base lens provides corrective refractive power.
5. The first lens portion is an elastically deformable lens chamber filled with a fluid or gel that changes shape or displaces along an optical axis in response to the contraction and relaxation of ciliary muscles.
6. The base lens is made of a substantially rigid material and does not readily deform or change its curvature.
7. Radially compressive forces exerted on the IOL device are transferred onto the lens chamber to cause the desired deforming changes.
8. The IOL device is resiliently biased to an unaccommodated state and actuates to an accommodated state in response to radial compressive forces.
9. The first lens is a biconvex lens, and the second lens is a one of a plano-convex lens, a bi-convex lens, or a positive meniscus lens.
10. The IOL device may further comprise a hinge, apertures, raised bumps, troughs, or radial arms to facilitate fluid communication and transfer of forces onto the lens chamber.

1. This invention is an esophageal-stomach displacement electrode that can be used for various medical procedures such as pacing, defibrillation, and ECG pickup.
2. The device includes a semi-rigid plastic tube with an electrode at the distal end, and a mechanism that allows the user to bend the last few inches of the tube back on itself to displace the stomach wall towards the heart.
3. This mechanism is similar to the one used in the prior application Ser. No. 07/589,995, and is controlled by a mechanism located at the proximal end of the tube outside the mouth.
4. The tube is crimped to form a hinge, and a rigid pin is disposed in the tube and extends generally parallel to the tube axis.
5. A pair of cords are connected to the proximal and distal ends of the pin and extend proximally in the tube out its proximal end and into the control mechanism. The location of the pin can be changed by pulling one or the other of the cords, causing the pin to move and the tube to bend at the hinge.

The present invention is a board game having a lake theme, where players can experience the ups and downs of life at a lake by acquiring, selling, mortgaging, and improving lake properties, dams, and boat dealerships. The game includes a square-shaped game board with a continuous path of spaces, tokens representing player identities, scrip money, Makin A Wake and Sunken Chest cards, and various lake-related game pieces.

The game is played by moving tokens along the path based on dice rolls, purchasing properties, paying rent to other players, and drawing Makin A Wake or Sunken Chest cards that can provide benefits, penalties, or instructions. Players can improve their properties by erecting lake cabins and marinas, and the game continues until all players except one are bankrupt, at which point the remaining player is declared the winner.

The present invention concerns a new device and method for treating tissues and open wounds and accomplishing directed tissue growth. Open wounds that cannot be sutured edge to edge are a major health problem, often becoming chronic due to poor blood supply, infection, and dehydration. The invention involves an apparatus for treating and regenerating tissues, covering a wound, combining liquid fluid supply and suction, which includes a pole, a rest movable in vertical directions along the pole and having a clamp for securing the rest at a height corresponding to the height of the tissue, at least one fluid reservoir placed on the rest and connected to the tissue, and means for controlling the fluid supply and suction. The rest can form an angle to the horizontal, be hinged and immobilized in any angle from horizontal to vertical, and have a range of vertical movement. The fluid reservoir can comprise a pliable and flexible bag filled with treatment fluid, and the controlling means can include a drip chamber, a roller clamp, a level meter, and an injection port connected with a tube. The apparatus can further comprise at least a drop-sensitive sensor for assessing the flow rate, and suction means comprising a suction pump placed on the platform and connected to the tissue by means of a tube. The pole can be u-shaped and fixed by means of a clamp to a hook which can be fastened to the footboard of a bed, straight and fixed to a base, or comprise telescoping parts which can be locked in position by means of screws, clamps, or a hydraulic mechanism. The apparatus can also comprise a motor which moves the rest in a vertical direction and is operable by means of a computer, ultrasound level meters, a pump used for administering the fluid supply, and means for monitoring the pressure head in the supply tube.

This application claims the benefit of several provisional and non-provisional patent applications related to gravity driven vehicles, specifically those that are steerable, have at least two wheels or skis, and are ridden in a prone, face down, face forward position. The invention also relates to a suspension mechanism for the wheels or skis that provides precise control in turns, especially when carving on snow covered terrain.

The text also describes various related patents and prior art in the field of non-motorized vehicle technology, and notes that the instant invention provides several advantages over these prior art inventions. The invention aims to provide a means for steering each wheel independently, absorbing shock from rough terrain, towing the vehicle to the top of an incline, and protecting the rider in case of a rollover. The invention also includes a kit of components for retrofitting a wheeled vehicle to one with wheels, skis, or a combination of both.

1. The present invention uses inverse wave techniques to reconstruct images of a medium surrounding a physical probe in a radial reflection configuration using a Hilbert-based wave algorithm.
2. The invention can be used for non-destructive evaluation of parts with existing access holes or media, such as arteries, and can form images of the plane perpendicular to the axis of rotation.
3. The invention can be mounted at the end of a flexible substrate, such as a catheter or snaking tube, and can be inserted into a part or medium to form images.
4. The invention can be used in a multimonostatic or multistatic arrangement, with one or more transmitting and receiving elements at a fixed radius.
5. The invention can be used for characterizing vulnerable atherosclerotic plaque, which can lead to cerebrovascular disease, the third leading cause of death and the leading cause of major disability among adults.
6. The invention can also be used for non-destructive characterization in applications other than intravascular imaging, such as characterizing buried wastes, tracking plumes of underground contaminants, or evaluating nondestructively parts having existing access holes.

1. The present invention is a biological oil composition derived from a marine copepod, preferably of the genus Calanus, and is rich in the fatty acids EPA and DHA, which are believed to be important in preventing cardiovascular disease.
2. The copepod oil of the present invention differs from other marine oils in its high content of the C18:4n-3 PUFA (stearidonic acid), and in the way its PUFAs exist predominantly as monoesters with long chain monounsaturated alcohols.
3. The biological oil composition of the present invention has been found to have a statistically significant ability to inhibit formation of atherosclerotic plaques, and to lower total blood cholesterol levels, compared to concentrated EPA/DHA.
4. The biological oil composition of the present invention is derived from a marine copepod using freshly harvested, frozen/thawed, or dehydrated raw material, and can be obtained by various methods such as conventional fish oil production technology, biotechnological methods, organic solvents, or supercritical fluid extraction.
5. The copepod oil of the present invention has a high wax ester content, which constitutes the major lipid component, unlike both cod liver oil and krill oil.
6. The most noteworthy difference in fatty acid composition between the copepod oil and other marine oils is the very high stearidonic acid (SDA) content in the copepod oil.

1. The invention describes pharmacological compositions containing polyelectrolyte complexes in microparticulate form and at least one active substance.
2. The active substance can be embedded in the matrix of the polyelectrolyte complex, itself be a partner in the polyelectrolyte complex, or be bound to a partner of the polyelectrolyte complex.
3. Active substances can be pharmacological active substances such as active peptides, proteins, enzymes, enzyme inhibitors, antigens, cytostatics, antibiotics, antiinflammatory agents, or vaccines.
4. Polyelectrolyte complexes can be formed by mixing alginate solutions and Ca2+ or by combining two macromolecular partners with different polarity.
5. The invention also covers the use of polyelectrolyte complexes as carrier substances and active substance components in the form of micro- or nanoparticles.
6. The microparticles can be prepared in various sizes and can be used for intravenous, subcutaneous, or oral administration.
7. The incorporation of an active substance in the polyelectrolyte complex particles/colloids can be carried out in several ways, including entrapment, absorption, precipitation, or by employing the active substance as a partner in the formation of the polyelectrolyte complex.
8. The invention also describes the use of polyelectrolyte complexes in the preparation of vaccines, wound ointment preparations, and ultrasonic contrast agents.

1. The invention is a golf ball teeing device that allows golfers to insert a golf tee into the ground with a ball on top without bending over.
2. Prior art devices use a clamping mechanism mounted on a long handle, which can be heavy, large, and expensive to produce.
3. These devices also require the golfer to manually unclamp the ball and tee, which can be cumbersome and time-consuming.
4. The invention instead uses a delayed urging means, such as low-recovery foam, to hold the ball and tee in place.
5. The device can be attached to a golf club grip, making it lightweight, portable, and easy to use.
6. The device also has a clip to attach it to a golf bag or clothing pocket.
7. The device automatically unclamps the ball and tee once the tee is pushed into the ground.
8. The golfer can use a golf club as the device handle, making it possible to tee up a golf ball from a standing position.
9. The device can also be used to retrieve golf tees from the ground.
10. The device is molded from an economical, flexible plastic material, but can be made from any material with the necessary elasticity and impact resistance.

1. The present disclosure relates to a person support apparatus, such as a hospital or long-term care bed, with a patient support deck and a mechanism for adjusting the height and orientation of the deck.
2. The deck is supported on a deck support frame, which is supported on leg assemblies pivotally connected at their upper end to the deck support frame and having linear actuators for pivoting the leg assemblies relative to the deck support frame.
3. Known arrangements for pivoting leg assemblies relative to a deck support frame have issues such as finger trapping, frictional forces, and dust collection.
4. The present disclosure provides a person support apparatus with a person support frame having an inverted substantially U-shaped channel element on its sides, and a leg assembly with a guide or follower element arranged to contact and run along an inner surface of the channel element.
5. This arrangement results in a robust and stable deck support frame that can accommodate changes in geometry necessary for movement or adjustment between the horizontal, Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions.
6. The channel and roller mechanism change the height of a patient support deck by pivoting one or more leg assemblies relative to the under surface of the patient support frame.
7. Features of some illustrative embodiments include a lower part count, an opening of the channel facing the floor, a reduced force necessary to lift the patient support frame, and a mechanism that makes it harder for a patient or care-giver to trap their fingers.
8. The deck support frame has two leg or support structures pivotally mounted to its under surface, each including a pair of legs connected together by a lower bracing cross-element at the bottom.
9. The lower cross-elements are each connected to a lower longitudinal or side element and able to rotate about their longitudinal axis, and the foot and head ends of the lower side elements each have a castor or castor device so that the support assembly can move over a floor.
10. A pair of stabilizer elements is connected to each pair of legs, and an actuator-stabilizer yoke is connected to each stabilizer cross-element, which is pivotally connected between the pair of stabilizers for each leg assembly. The actuator-stabilizer yoke is pivotally coupled to an end of

1. The text describes a skin reflectance measuring apparatus, which is a continuation of a previously abandoned application.
2. The apparatus measures skin reflectance, which can be associated with other parameters such as sebum secretion rate, making it useful in studying seborrhea and other skin diseases, as well as in cosmetology for testing anti-reflectance products and grading different types of skin.
3. The apparatus uses a probe with a casing and an aperture, connected to a measuring device via a flexible fiber optic cable with three optical conductors.
4. The measuring device includes light emitting and receiving means, which produce signals representing specular and diffuse reflection, and processing means that compensate for variations in light intensity and ambient light to produce a relative reflectance signal.

1. The invention is a dental cleaning and massaging apparatus that includes a mouthpiece with upper and lower channel members that fit over the teeth and snugly against the gums, and pneumatic and hydraulic means for moving the channel members to massage the gums and clean and flush out the teeth and gums.
2. The mouthpiece is made of a relatively soft but semi-rigid material and includes a first outer membrane and a second inner membrane that enclose the area between the upper and lower channel members, forming a sealed area.
3. A plurality of bite blocks are located in both upper and lower channel members, and a hose or tube with air-sacks is positioned between the bottom of the upper channel member and the top of the lower channel member.
4. The apparatus is connected to a control box that provides air pulses and water or air pulses alone or water alone, and includes suction hoses to remove any fluid that seeps out during use.

1. The present invention relates to pelvic floor reconstruction using implants, specifically addressing the issues of reliable anchoring and minimally invasive surgery.
2. The invention includes a needle with a trap for securing the implant strap, a tip for threading the strap, and a mechanism for releasing the trap, allowing for threading from the accessible side of the tissue.
3. The invention also includes anterior and posterior implants designed for specific reconstructive purposes, with straps for threading into ligaments and loops for anchoring to the cervix or perineal body.
4. The methods for using the needle and installing the implants are also described, with an emphasis on minimally invasive techniques.

1. The invention describes methods and apparatus for providing ventilatory assistance matched to a subject's respiratory need, suitable for spontaneously or non-spontaneously breathing subjects, particularly those requiring long-term assistance during sleep.
2. The invention aims to address the challenges of accurately matching the amplitude and phase of mask pressure to the subject's spontaneous efforts, maintaining adequate ventilatory support during sleep, and adjusting the degree of support in the presence of leaks or abnormalities in respiratory control.
3. The methods involve determining the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle, calculating leak-corrected respiratory airflow, and applying fuzzy inference rules to determine the fuzzy extent to which the phase is a specific value, followed by defuzzification to determine the instantaneous phase.
4. The apparatus includes transducers, processors, flow generators, and gas delivery means to provide breathable gas at a pressure above atmospheric pressure.
5. The algorithms can be approximated without the use of fuzzy logic formalism, and the methods can be applied to various ventilatory devices, including ventilators, ventilatory assist devices, and CPAP devices.

1. The invention describes an electro-surgical dissecting and cauterizing instrument for use in standard endoscopic procedures, which can also be used in open surgeries.
2. The instrument has a distal, working tip electrode connected to a proximal end with an electric plug that can be connected to a conventional electro-surgical unit.
3. The electric energy is delivered to the distal, working tip of the tool via a conductive rod surrounded by a linear, rigid sleeve formed of an insulating material.
4. The distal end of the tool includes an electrically conductive, rigid arm extending from the sleeve portion of the tool, with portions laterally offset from the longitudinal axis of the sleeve.
5. The working tip electrode is formed at the free end of the arm and is used to make direct contact with the patient at the internal operation site.
6. A thin jacket of insulating material is disposed upon the arm from the point where it extends from the sleeve right up to, but not including, the working tip electrode.
7. The working tip electrode comes in many different shapes depending on the needs of the surgeon in a particular surgical application.
8. The offset arm design provides for maximum visualization of the working tip electrode and operation site by the surgeon.
9. The invention aims to improve the surgeon's view of the operation site and prevent unintentional cauterization of healthy tissue with portions of the tool other than the working tip electrode.

1. The invention describes a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) apparatus that allows high-contrast exposures in a short time for larger body segments.
2. The MRI apparatus includes a magnet, a patient receptacle, a support plate, and a predetermined number of transmit and/or receive coils.
3. The required adjustment parameters are determined in a preceding adjustment process and used in a subsequent exposure process.
4. The adjustment parameters can be modified by changing the position of the support plate or by connecting/disconnecting the transmit and/or receive coils.
5. The adjustment parameters are stored in a memory until the end of the examination and can be reused when identical or similar exposure parameters are reached.
6. The invention is suitable for various forms of MRI apparatuses, including cylindrical and horseshoe magnets.
7. The MRI apparatus allows for reduced examination times and high-contrast exposures, making it suitable for tracking contrast agent doses over larger body regions.

1. The present invention is a releasable fastener for albums with front and back covers and removable pages between the covers.
2. The fastener includes a pair of strap anchors, a strap, and means for providing a releasable connection between the strap and each of the strap anchors.
3. The strap anchors are in the form of a channel, and the strap is a snap lock that is releasably locked therein against displacement.
4. The strap is snap-locked into the channel by snapping engagement beneath locking lips at an open side of the channel facing the base of the channel.
5. The base of the channel and opposing surface of the strap have formations that prevent longitudinal displacement of the strap within the channel when it's in its engaged position beneath the lips.
6. The strap anchors can be adhesively attached to the respective covers, for example by double-sided adhesive tape.
7. The album fastener provides a more convenient and secure way to add or replace album pages compared to conventional screw-type fasteners.
8. The cross-sectional profile of the strap is designed to facilitate both its insertion into and its removal from the channel.
9. The opposed end portions of the strap will be attached to the strap anchors on the front and back covers, and the strap is of a length to permit adjustment of the album by incorporating additional sets of album pages as required.

The present invention describes a new sulky design that can be manufactured using lightweight and durable materials, and assembled easily by users from flat elements. This design allows for the use of casting and mass production, resulting in a 40% weight reduction and a more stable construction. The end frames are designed to be identical and interchangeable, and can be easily packed and transported in a flat package. The use of color tapes for customization is also suggested.

1. The invention is a ventilation system for rotating water feeds, particularly useful for water-cooled generators with coaxial feed and discharge ducts.
2. The system aims to eliminate air or gas bubbles in the cooling system to prevent local overheating and blockage of flow paths.
3. The invention provides at least one bypass with an inlet in the space around the axis of rotation and outlets between the feed duct and the discharge duct.
4. This arrangement utilizes the pressure gradient between the inflow and outflow for automatic removal of air or gas bubbles.
5. The bypass can be arranged in or on an end face of the feed ducts, or as a radially arranged pipe member with an inlet in the space around the axis of rotation.
6. In a further embodiment, the bypass can be designed as a coiled pipe with at least one inlet opening into the space around the axis of rotation.
7. The bypass can also include means for increasing the hydrodynamic resistance of flow through the bypass, enabling a smaller ventilation system with low resistance to flow.
8. The system defines an axis of rotation, and the bypass outlets open into the axial feed duct or discharge duct in the direction of flow.
9. The invention eliminates air or gas bubbles by providing inlet openings in the space around the lowest pressure point, enabling effective ventilation.

1. The invention describes a steering column for a motor vehicle that has a jacket unit supporting a steering shaft and a retaining part that the jacket unit is secured to in a non-displaceable manner up to a limit value of a force acting parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft.
2. The jacket unit is connected to the retaining part through an energy absorption connection and a break-away connection.
3. The energy absorption connection comprises at least one bending wire or strip that is deformed when the jacket unit is displaced with respect to the retaining part, and the break-away connection is closed and blocks displacement of the jacket unit with respect to the retaining part up to the limit value of the force.
4. The break-away connection is released if the limit value of the force is exceeded, allowing the jacket unit to become displaceable parallel to the longitudinal axis in the direction toward the motor vehicle front.
5. The invention also relates to a method for the production of such a steering column.

The present invention describes a method for installing flat uncontoured glass panels in curved window bays of motor vehicles, using a process that flexes the glass into the conforming curvature of the window, and then applies a weather sealant and adhesive compound in situ along the confronting edges of the window panel. This method aims to overcome the disadvantages of conventional methods, such as the distortion, brittleness, and high cost of pre-contoured glass panels, and the structural weakness of window openings when pre-contoured glass breaks during an accident.

1. The present invention is a method and apparatus for removing a gas from a liquid, specifically for separating oxygen from water in offshore hydrocarbon recovery platforms.
2. Current methods for removing oxygen from water include stripping towers and vacuum techniques, but these often cannot remove oxygen to trace levels and require the use of chemical scavengers.
3. The invention describes a mechanical, cylindrical gas scavenger machine with a reduced height and no chemical scavenger treatment, which is particularly suited for use on offshore floating platforms.
4. The apparatus includes a vessel with multiple partitions dividing it into gasification chambers, each with a vapor space and no communication between vapor spaces of adjacent chambers.
5. A mechanism for ingesting and mixing a second gas into the liquid of each gasification chamber creates a turbulent area and displaces at least a portion of the first gas to the vapor space of each chamber.
6. A vent in each chamber removes gas, and a liquid outlet from the outlet chamber allows for the removal of the treated liquid.
7. The invention can be used with various liquids and gases, and the replaced gas, the liquid containing the new gas, or both may be the desired product of the process.
8. The method of the invention is a continuous process, and the amount of second gas ingestion should be controlled to achieve the desired removal level for the first gas.
9. Advantages of the invention include decreased vessel height requirements, reduced capital costs, and the ability to handle liquids with appreciable amounts of the second gas.

1. The document describes a packaging machine with a shaft that drives the tool members of multiple work stations, synchronizing their movements and simplifying the design of the machine.
2. The shaft is arranged in the production direction of the packaging machine and is connected to a drive, such as an electric motor or servomotor.
3. Transfer mechanisms, such as toggle levers or cam mechanisms, convert the rotational movement of the shaft into the desired movement of the tool members.
4. The packaging machine can include work stations for forming, evacuating and sealing, and separating or cutting, and can be arranged on different vertical levels to save space.
5. The machine also includes a frame to support the shaft and prevent vibrations, and tool members that can be displaced in the production direction to adapt to different packaging materials or package shapes.

1. This invention relates to finishing articles with a mounting hub permanently affixed for quick attachment and release to a power tool.
2. The mounting hub is typically affixed with an adhesive, but this can lead to problems with the grinding wheel rotating relative to the mounting hub.
3. To solve this problem, keyways and corresponding keys are used between the wheel and the mounting hub.
4. The present invention uses a disposable finishing article drive member assembly that places the grinding wheel in compression when in use, securing it to the spindle.
5. The assembly includes a backing flange, a retaining nut, and a pressure cap that engages the power tool spindle seat for placing the abrasive finishing article in compression.
6. The retaining nut and backing flange are secured together without the use of adhesives, and the pressure cap is easily snapped into place.
7. This design provides a secure attachment of the abrasive finishing article to the power tool, is vibration-free, and meets all current safety standards.

1. The invention describes a hydraulic unit for a vehicle brake system that includes a housing block, a motor, a housing, and a covering hood.
2. The motor is secured to the housing block and has a shaft trunnion, eccentric, and shaft that determine a pivot axis for an eccentric chamber.
3. Two piston pumps are provided, each with piston pumps and outlet valves, and are fixed in the housing block.
4. The piston pumps are displaceable by the eccentric to generate pressure and are connected to storage pistons and springs in cylindrical bores.
5. First conduit portions extend downward from the eccentric chamber and discharge into the spring chambers to collect pressure fluid entrained by the piston pump piston.
6. Closure elements are provided in the cylindrical bores to prevent dirt and water from penetrating and to catch pressure fluid.
7. A generic pressure equalization conduit exists between the spring chambers and the interior of the motor, allowing air to escape and pressure to equalize.
8. A pressure equilibrium is created between the interior of the motor and the housing, which is sealed off relative to the housing block, by a pressure equalization conduit formed by interstices between wires of a cable and a tubular cable sheath.
9. The provisions directly prevent the invasion of water to the hydraulic unit yet provide a pressure equalization of interiors of the hydraulic unit with the ambient atmosphere, and they moreover bring about the diversion of pressure fluid, entrained by pump pistons, into a region of the unit that is located far from vulnerable electrical parts of the hydraulic unit.

1. This text describes a power and free conveyor system with a mechanism for transferring carriers from one predetermined path to another.
2. The system includes a third dog that can be moved to an operative pushing position to transfer the carrier across short or long distances.
3. The second and third dogs have cam projections that engage portions of the track, holding them out of operative position until needed for transfer.
4. The system allows for selective transfer of the carrier, minimizing cost and maintenance while accommodating various systems with varying transfer distances.
5. The invention can be applied to the transfer of a carrier from one powered conveyor to another, either from a faster to a slower conveyor or vice versa, or between conveyors moving at the same speed.

1. The document describes a rail car center plate assembly bowl liner made of a special type of ultra high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMW-PE) that is self-lubricating and conductive, eliminating the need for additional grounding apparatus.
2. The liner has a dished, bowl-like configuration with a floor or disc portion and an upstanding side wall, and is designed to fully fill the space between the truck bolster bowl and the body bolster center plate.
3. The liner is made of a high density polymer of dry self-lubricating characteristics that is pliable but non-stretchable, and is mixed with a conductive material such as 2% carbon black to make it conductive.
4. The liner is designed to withstand loads imposed by cars having a mass bearing on each center bowl on the order of 25,000 to 122,000 pounds, and to preserve its self-lubricating feature as well as wear resistance and resistance to compression, deterioration and disintegration.

1. The invention describes a gate valve designed for controlling the bulk dispensing of viscous substances, particularly in fast-food restaurants where one-handed operation is desirable.
2. The valve is to be mounted on the spout of a bag or pouch and includes a tubular sleeve that fits into the spout, a dispensing passage, and a reciprocable gate.
3. The gate is guided by a transversely-curved plate and can be opened or closed by engaging cooperating lugs with fingers, allowing for variable flow or complete cut-off.
4. The valve is illustrated in the accompanying drawings, which show the valve in various views and its assembly on the spout of a bag supported in a dispenser.
5. The valve comprises a spout insert mounting sleeve, a passage with a discharge outlet and sealing edge, and an annular stop shoulder.
6. A gate valve guide member is formed integrally with the sleeve and extends radially outwardly to guide the gate valve member during reciprocal movement.
7. The gate valve member comprises a curved transverse plate with guide-receiving formations that receive the opposite side edges of the guide plate.
8. The gate valve member is reciprocated on the guide member by an integral upward guide and operating channel-like extension.
9. The valve can be disassembled for cleaning by applying sufficient downward force on the gate valve member, causing the resilient lugs to yield.
10. The valve can function in inclined positions and can be actuated with one hand only, making it suitable for use in dispensers.

<summary> The document describes a vehicle rearview mirror system that can adapt to different protocols of a vehicle control output. The system includes a mirror control that determines the protocol of the output by monitoring its state and adjusting a running average parameter. If the running average parameter exceeds certain limits, the system sets the protocol to a more appropriate value. The system also includes an ignition-cycle average parameter that is adjusted only upon vehicle power-up to reduce the likelihood of anomalies affecting performance. The system can be implemented in software, reducing hardware expenses and utilizing an 8-bit register. </summary>

1. The document describes an anti-lock braking system for motorcycles with an anti-dive device for a damped telescopic front suspension.
2. The anti-dive device is designed to reduce chassis vibration caused by the repeated operation of the anti-lock control unit.
3. The anti-lock control unit rapidly cycles the brake on and off to prevent wheel lock-up during braking.
4. The anti-dive device can be tapped into the hydraulic pressure line downstream of the anti-lock control unit or can sense the reaction to braking force on the front wheel.
5. The system includes a front wheel brake operated by a master cylinder and an anti-lock control unit interposed in the brake line.
6. The anti-lock control unit senses the nearly-locked condition of the front wheel and shuts off the hydraulic pressure to the brake.
7. The chassis vibration occurs in a vertical direction and is more pronounced in motorcycles with high centers of gravity and short wheelbases.
8. The reaction to braking force causes the front fork to dive, which can decrease braking efficiency during the short period when there is no increase in front wheel load.
9. The anti-dive device is designed to reduce this decrease in braking efficiency and improve overall braking performance.
10. The document includes diagrams and illustrations of the system and its components.

The text describes an improved partition system for dividing the cargo space of a trailer into separate areas that can be maintained at different temperatures. The system includes at least two panels that are independently attached to one or more mounting assemblies, allowing each panel to be moved independently. In a preferred embodiment, two bulkheads or panels are slidably attached to separate pairs of ceiling-mounted rails in a refrigerated trailer, and can be moved toward the front or rear of the trailer to define different cargo areas. In another embodiment, two half-width bulkheads are secured to one another and independently slidably attached to the ceiling of the trailer, allowing each half-width bulkhead to be raised and lowered with minimal fore and aft clearance. The panels can be moved and stowed using a variety of mechanisms, including trolley assemblies, lift mechanisms, and straps.

1. The text describes a novel sanitizable rotary valve used in conjunction with liquid chromatographic columns and sanitary liquid handling systems to separate and/or purify biological macromolecules of importance to the pharmaceutical industry.
2. The valve is designed to allow for simulated moving bed counter-current operation and can be partially separated for cleaning, with a novel diaphragm-like elastomeric seal retaining sanitizing process fluids during cleaning.
3. The valve is used in a larger system for continuous counterflow fractionation, including an SMB size exclusion fractionation separation system and an SMB ion exchange fractionation separation system.

1. The text describes an improved valve-tray assembly for gas-liquid contacting trays, which incorporates directional thrust valves and tray construction for higher efficiency operation.
2. The invention aims to address the problem of restricted disengagement of vapor retained in the liquid in gas-liquid contact columns.
3. The text also discusses the history of prior art in gas-liquid contact columns, including the use of trays, packing, and their combinations, and the trend towards replacing bubble caps with sieve and valve trays.

1. The present invention is a fluid pressure regulator assembly that regulates fluid pressure while also generating power.
2. The assembly includes a pressurized fluid source, a vane motor that converts fluid pressure into mechanical power, a fluid regulator, and a generator that converts the mechanical power into electrical energy.
3. The vane motor is a type of positive displacement pump that uses vanes to pump fluid and can be used to generate electricity or mechanical power.
4. The fluid regulator regulates the pressure of the fluid, and the generator is electrically coupled to a battery which, in turn, is coupled to an electrically actuated rotisserie or any other desired components.
5. The vane motor is constructed of stainless steel with wear-resistant tips and is positioned so that the fluid enters the motor at a specific angle to maximize efficiency.
6. The vanes of the motor extend and retract relative to the inner drum to reduce reverse torque and increase forward torque.
7. The assembly is particularly useful in applications where a fluid pressure regulator is already being used, such as in gas grills, scuba gear, and medical equipment, as it can reduce the size and cost of the regulator while also generating power.

1. The invention describes a pallet system with a pallet cap that has guide rails for loading trays and end plates for securing the load, providing stability and protecting the edges of the trays.
2. The guide rails are customized to fit the pockets of a conventional plastic pallet and are designed to interlock adjacent trays, while the end stops limit the longitudinal movement of the trays.
3. The end plates are shaped to complement the contour of the trays and can be used with pallets of different sizes, nesting within one another when not in use.
4. The components of the pallet system can be made of various materials and manufactured by different methods, and the features can be customized for the intended load.

1. The invention describes an electrical driven flying saucer based on magnetic suspension, which includes a saucer shell, a saucer cabin, a rotary-wing system, and a control system.
2. The rotary-wing system is a magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing system, which comprises magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels, an electromotive ring, a magnetic suspension shaft, and a magnetic suspension guide rail.
3. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels are suspended in the space restricted by the electromotive ring, the magnetic suspension shaft, and the magnetic suspension guide rail and go around the magnetic suspension shaft under an electromagnetic thrust.
4. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels, the electromotive ring, and the magnetic suspension shaft constitute a magnetic suspension electric engine.
5. The electromotive ring is a stator, the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels constitute a rotor, and the magnetic suspension shaft is a spindle.
6. The electromotive ring controls the changes of the current flowing in the electromotive ring according to electromagnetic conversion principle and generates a rotating magnetic field along the ring.
7. This rotating magnetic field generates a magnetic force upon the magnetic field in the magnetic suspension outer ring of the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels and pushes the rotation of the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels.
8. Two sets of independent magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing systems are superposed and mounted coaxially inside the saucer shell in the axial direction or radial direction.
9. This design can guarantee the coaxial thrusts in the same direction will overcome or offset the reactive torque generated during rotation of the rotary wings and may realize automatic control for self-rotating angles and self-rotating angular velocity of the flying saucer.
10. The design of the rotary-wing suspension structure avoids the contact and friction between the high-speed rotary-wing and the interior of the saucer shell, reduces the noise of the rotary wing during high-speed rotation as well as the vibration of the saucer shell and the saucer cabin, raises motive power conversion efficiency, lowers energy consumption, and guarantees the operational safety of the rotary wing and the flying saucer.

1. The present invention describes streptavidin muteins, a process for their production using recombinant DNA technology, and their use for isolating, purifying, and determining biological substances, particularly recombinant proteins.
2. The biotin/streptavidin system is widely used in molecular biology, but its application is limited by the need for biotinylated reagents, which must be obtained in a pure form.
3. The invention describes a method for modifying the biotin/streptavidin system using peptide ligands that can be coexpressed with a desired protein, eliminating the need for biotinylation and resulting in a more economical process.
4. The streptavidin peptide ligand system allows for the purification of recombinant proteins under mild elution conditions and enables their detection using streptavidin conjugates.
5. The invention also describes a method for improving the binding affinity of the streptavidin/peptide ligand system using mutations in the streptavidin sequence.

The text describes a nickel-catalyzed method for guanylating amines or pyrrolidines with guanylating agents such as thioureas or isothioureas. The nickel catalyst, preferably in the zero oxidation state, can be derived from various alloys or supports and is advantageous due to its low cost and high recoverability. The reaction yields high percentages of substituted guanidines, even with low catalyst loadings.

1. The invention describes a method and apparatus for continuously electrolytically coloring aluminum strips or wires, which overcomes the weatherability and fading issues of conventional methods.
2. The method involves a two-step process: first, anodic oxidation of aluminum strips or wires to form an oxide film, followed by electrolytic coloring of the anodic coating in a bath containing specific acid or metal salt.
3. The apparatus includes an anodic oxidation bath, an electrolytic coloring bath, a power source, and a means for passing the aluminum strip or wire continuously through the baths.
4. The anodic oxidation bath composition contains sulfuric acid, with optional additives, and forms an oxide film thicker than 4 microns on the aluminum surface.
5. The electrolytic coloring bath contains at least one of nickel, cobalt, copper, tin salts, or selenious acid, and the aluminum strip or wire functions as a cathode, colored by the action of an electrode in the bath.

1. The invention describes a process of rapid, inexpensive in planta assembly of a DNA sequence of interest designed for stable integration into a plant chromosome, which allows for fast optimization of the sequences to be expressed, screening libraries of coding or regulatory sequences of interest, design of safer vectors, and avoiding difficult cloning during the design of complex DNA regions for stable nuclear transformation.
2. The assembly, optimization and identification of a desired DNA sequence of interest for stable nuclear transformation of plant cells can be performed with high efficiency in planta, thus be combined with plant transformation as a one step procedure.

1. The invention describes a swash plate type compressor with a coated swash plate to reduce frictional wear and increase durability and efficiency.
2. The swash plate is coated with a heat curable, cross-linked coating comprising a polyfluoro elastomer, a lubricious additive, and a load bearing additive.
3. The coating is bonded directly to the aluminum swash plate and cured in an oven at an elevated temperature.
4. The piston shoe may also be coated with the fluorocarbon coating to further increase the low friction properties of the compressor.
5. The coating allows for the use of lower cost, low silicon aluminum base material for the swash plate without the need for metal plating or high finish polishing.
6. The coating provides a durable, low coefficient of friction surface that increases the life of the compressor and its efficiency.

1. The present invention relates to organic polymers suitable for use in anti-reflective coatings on semiconductor devices, and methods for preparing them.
2. The polymers are designed to facilitate light absorption at wavelengths of 193 nm and 248 nm by having groups that absorbs light strongly at both wavelengths.
3. The polymers can be used to form a layer which prevents the reflection of light from lower layers coated on a semiconductor chip when photolithography processes using short wavelength light sources are employed.
4. The anti-reflective coating composition of the present invention is prepared by dissolving a polymer in an organic solvent, and subsequently adding thereto one or more compounds selected from Tables 1a and 1b.
5. The polymers and compositions of the present invention have proven to be excellent organic anti-reflective coating materials during the formation of submicro-patterns in photolithographic processes using 248 nm KrF and 193 nm ArF lasers.

1. The invention describes a white, flame-retardant, UV-resistant, thermoformable, oriented film made from a crystallizable thermoplastic with a thickness of 10 to 350 μm, containing white pigment, flame retardant, and UV absorber.
2. The film has good orientability, thermoformability, and optical and mechanical properties, and can be produced cost-effectively.
3. Previous films lack UV absorbers and flame retardants, resulting in poor performance in fire tests and photooxidative degradation in outdoor applications.
4. EP-A-0 620 245 discloses films with improved heat resistance but no UV resistance proposal, while DE-A 2346 787 describes a flame-retardant polymer with hydrolysis susceptibility and embrittlement issues.
5. The invention aims to provide a film that is flame-retardant, does not embrittle on heat exposure, is thermoformable, and has high UV resistance, all while being cost-effective and having good optical and mechanical properties.
6. The film's flame retardancy is defined by DIN 4102 Part 2 and Part 1 standards, and it should pass the UL 94 test for VTM-0 classification.
7. High UV resistance means minimal damage from sunlight or UV radiation, preserving the film's color, flexibility, and mechanical properties even after years of outdoor use.
8. Thermoformability allows the film to be shaped into complex and large-surface-area moldings without uneconomic predrying.
9. Good optical properties include uniform coloration, high surface gloss, low light transmission, and a stable Yellowness Index. Good mechanical properties consist of high modulus of elasticity and good tensile stress at break values.

1. The present invention provides an improved method for producing 143a (1,1,1-trifluoroethane) by continuous gas phase hydrofluorination of 1,1-difluoro-1-chloroethane using heterogeneous catalysis.
2. The invention aims to provide a simple, convenient, economical, industrial process for the manufacturing of 143a with very high conversion and very high selectivity (both over 99%).
3. Previous methods for synthesizing 143a have been known, but they often involve undesirable co-products or are not practical for industrial-scale production.
4. The catalysts used in the invention are a combination of iron oxide, rare earth oxide, and zirconium oxide, or a chromium (III) chloride supported on alumina.
5. The process can produce 143a with high selectivity and conversion, but the catalyst requires a long time for regeneration, which is not practical for industrial applications.
6. The invention also discloses a process for removing low levels of olefinic material from 143a using a separate fixed bed post-reactor with the same Cr/Ni/AlF3 catalyst as the main reactor.
7. The temperature used for operating this downstream reactor is much lower than the main reactor temperature, and the process can convert olefinic materials to the corresponding saturated products 141b, 142b and 143a.
8. The process can be carried out in a separate fixed bed post-reactor, downstream from the main reactor, without distilling HCl or HF from the crude product.
9. The post reactor contains the same catalyst, Cr/Ni/AlF3, as the main reactor, and the temperature used for operating this downstream reactor is much lower than the main reactor temperature.

1. The invention describes an improved process for the deacylation and desulfurization of a compound using hypophosphorous acid to improve product yield and reduce impurities.
2. Pyrazolotriazoles, useful as magenta couplers in photographic products, are difficult to synthesize with only a few synthetic routes known.
3. The improved process involves the preparation of triazolothiadiazines, which can be converted to pyrazolotriazoles through a two-step desulfurization process.
4. The first step is a ring contraction reaction in acetic anhydride, while the second step is hydrolysis and desulfurization with hydrochloric acid.
5. However, the hydrolysis and desulfurization reactions generate elemental sulfur and sulfur-containing organic impurities, which can interfere with subsequent reactions and cause fogging in photographic systems.
6. The use of hypophosphorous acid in the deacylation and desulfurization step reduces the amount of these impurities and increases the yield of the desired product.
7. The hypophosphorous acid also results in the formation of hydrogen sulfide by-product, which is readily removed from the reaction zone.
8. The invention provides a significant advance in the art by overcoming significant difficulties and providing several advantages, making it readily adaptable by industry.

1. The invention describes a method and apparatus for forming fiber mixtures from different fiber types by sequentially taking partial quantities from fiber bales.
2. The method measures the entire momentary quantity of each fiber lot and calculates a partial quantity that corresponds to a predetermined proportion of the momentary entire quantity.
3. The apparatus includes a bale opener, a quantity measuring device, and a control device that controls the mode of operation of the opener based on signals from the quantity measuring device.
4. The method ensures that the opening of all fiber bales is effected without fiber residuals and further, that an optimally homogeneous mixture is obtained.

The present invention describes a method and apparatus for forming bias laid, non-woven fabrics, where the yarns in at least two of the layers are laid at an angle to the long axis of the fabric. These yarns are held together by stitching through the layers, knitting with a loose stitch, or adhesive bonding threads of the layers at crossing points. The most desirable fabrics for structural purposes have at least two layers with yarns at a 45 degree angle to the long axis of the fabric, lying at 90 degrees to each other.

The invention also describes a rake mechanism, driven separately from the conveyors, yarn carrying means, and bonding mechanism, which is used to achieve greater assurance of parallelism of the yarns and to better control the strength and thickness of the resulting layer. The rake mechanism accepts and retains the yarns being carried by the yarn carrying means at either end of the extremities of travel of the yarn carrying means, and places the yarns onto or between the appropriate needles on the conveyors of the fabric forming mechanism. The rake mechanism can move a distance which is the same as the width of the yarns being carried by the yarn carrying means, or a distance equivalent to only a portion of the width of the yarns, resulting in partial overlapping of return courses onto the course first laid.

The present invention describes methods and apparatus for inserting weft threads with varying thickness in a multiple-color air jet loom, by adjusting the pressure or duration of air blasts to suit each thread type. This results in stable weft insertion and reduced consumption of pressurized air.

The different embodiments describe various ways of achieving this, such as using subnozzles with different orifice diameters, supplying air under different pressures, or varying the interval of time in which air is ejected. The invention can be applied to air jet looms using more than two different weft threads, and can also be used in looms without subnozzles.

<summary> The present invention describes a process for spinning bast fibers, such as jute, kenaf, or hemp, which includes health preserving the fibers in specific temperature, humidity, and duration conditions to improve flexibility and spinnability. This process can be used for spinning bast fibers alone or blended with other fibers. The invention also includes a bast fibers yarn and a multi-fibre yarn produced through this process. Examples of the process using different types of bast fibers and blends with other fibers are provided, demonstrating a reduction in end breakage rate during spinning. </summary>

1. The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for measuring and removing the effects of rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of nip presses used in various industries, with a focus on papermaking.
2. Nipped rolls are used to exert pressing forces on webs for forming materials like paper, textile, plastic foil, and the nip pressure profile is crucial for achieving uniform sheet characteristics.
3. The invention uses multiple sensors circumferentially spaced at various cross-directional positions along the sensing roll to cancel the effects of rotational variability and provide a more accurate nip pressure profile.
4. The sensors take multiple pressure measurements at each cross-directional position during each 360° revolution of the sensing roll, which are used to obtain an average pressure measurement and calculate the nip pressure profile.
5. The variability of the readings at each position is monitored to determine if the roll rotational variability is stable or increasing, which may indicate potential failures in the bearings or roll cover.
6. The system can also calculate and display the rotational variability profile, providing the operator with additional real-time information to obtain a more accurate nip pressure profile.
7. The present invention can compensate for rotational variability in the sensing mechanism, improving the accuracy of the nip pressure profile and helping to eliminate or compensate for pressure variability at locations across the sensing roll.

1. The invention is a combination electrical cord support and article holder for an ironing board.
2. The electrical cord support keeps the cord above the ironing surface and includes an outlet for the plug.
3. The article holder provides a convenient place to store items like spray starch or a beverage container.
4. The article holder can be removed when not in use to save space.
5. The clamp that attaches the device to the ironing board is C-shaped with an adjusting screw to secure it.
6. The cord support is a flexible mast with a coiled spring resilient section to support the cord.
7. The article holder is a circular hoop with support bars that can hold various items.
8. The device also includes an extension portion for mounting a female electrical outlet.

1. The invention describes a buttonhole controlling device for a sewing machine that can create buttonholes of consistent length regardless of the type of material being sewn.
2. The device includes a foot pad attached to a presser bar, a travelling assembly with a slidable member, and an adjustable stop.
3. The slidable member can be positioned by a button for which a buttonhole is to be sewn and carries a tab to actuate a tripping lever on the machine.
4. The adjustable stop engages the tripping lever to terminate the formation of a buttonhole, allowing the operator to precisely define the closure point.
5. The device controls the operation of a tripping lever, which in turn controls flexible contacts to cause the machine to sew a buttonhole when in a buttonhole mode.
6. The device is adjustable to compensate for possible slippage in different amounts of various materials.
7. The invention is applicable to electronic sewing machines and can be used to sew buttonholes in garments made of different types of materials.

1. The present invention is an apparatus for treating a dyed or printed textile web with a liquid, such as a washing or rinsing solution.
2. The apparatus includes a conveyor, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch.
3. The conveyor is an endless sieve belt that transports the textile web along a predetermined horizontal path.
4. The applicator applies the liquid to the web during motion, and the suction device removes the liquid from the web by a suction process during motion.
5. The dwell stretch conducts the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop.
6. The dwell stretch lengthens the action time of the applied liquid on the substances to be removed from the web, allowing for more effective washing or rinsing.
7. The apparatus is especially suitable for treating printed material, as it can effectively wash the material without soiling a white background or causing smudges in the printed matter.

1. The dry cleaning machine of the present invention provides an air flow system for bringing ambient air into the access opening whenever the door is opened which is exclusive of the air recirculating system and substantially reduces exhausting the residual solvent vapors from the tubs.
2. A separate intake fan and duct is provided with the duct interposed between the access opening of the machine housing and the open ends of the interior tubs, and includes a normally closed valve so that during normal operation of the machine the separate intake system is isolated from the solvent vapors developed during the cleaning cycle.
3. The dry cleaner includes a pair of nested tubs having a common horizontal access with the outer tub generally stationarily supported and the inner tub rotatably supported, and an outer cabinet having an access opening in alignment with the open end of the tubs and supporting a front opening door for access to the inner tub.
4. The operative cycle of the machine includes a washing portion, a drain portion, a spin or centrifuging portion, and a drying portion.
5. The solvent flow system includes a pump for pumping the dry cleaning solvent from a storage tank into the tub through a filter in the housing, and a blower for circulating heated air through the tubs for drying the clothes.
6. The air flow system includes a header chamber attached to the outer tub at the tub's forward opening, and a pair of airflow hoses attached to the header chamber. Each hose is associated with an electrically energized oneway valve for controlling the flow through these hoses.
7. During the spin cycle, valves associated with the air inlet and outlet sides of the tubs are closed to isolate the air within the tubs and prevent any air circulation through the air distributing system, which minimizes the undesirable phenomena associated with dry cleaning referred to as "streaks and swales".

1. The present invention describes a method and apparatus for forming a melt spun nonwoven web using a new spinning process that combines the advantages of eductive and non-eductive systems, while improving web formation control by incorporating aspects of the meltblown process.
2. The process involves providing a thermoplastic polymer in a fluid condition, spinning filaments through a spinneret into a quench chamber, and drawing the filaments through a narrowing lower end of the quenching chamber into an impingement point slot opening where high velocity quench air draws and cools the filaments.
3. The apparatus includes a web forming table with a vacuum suction box and a moving mesh wire belt conveyor to receive the filaments and form them into a non-woven web, which can then be strengthened by conventional techniques and wound into rolls.
4. The process and apparatus are designed to produce low basis weight webs from fine polypropylene or polyester filaments, with high production rates and good web formation uniformity, making them suitable for various applications including sanitary products, garments, surgical drapes, industrial filtration, automotive carpet, roofing applications, and hygiene products.

1. The document describes a sewing machine, an embroidery unit, and a non-transitory computer-readable medium storing a sewing machine control program that allow sewing in a position specified on a work cloth.
2. The sewing machine includes an imaging portion to capture an image of a marker affixed to a specified position on the work cloth, and automatically set the sewing position and angle based on the captured image.
3. However, this method requires affixing and removing the marker, which can be troublesome for the user.
4. Embodiments provide a sewing machine with at least one detecting portion to detect an ultrasonic wave from a transmission source and identify the position of the transmission source based on the detected ultrasonic wave.
5. The embroidery unit can be attached to and detached from the bed of the sewing machine and includes at least one detecting portion to detect an ultrasonic wave and a notifying portion to notify the sewing machine of the detection timing.
6. The sewing machine controls the movement of the embroidery frame based on the position of the transmission source identified by the sewing machine.
7.
